title: 109_s738
content: The Act is named the "Cotton Shirt Industry Tariff Relief and Technical Corrections Act." It includes temporary duty reductions for certain cotton shirting fabrics. Woven fabrics of cotton, certified for making men's and boys' shirts, subject to quantity limitations under general note 18. Woven fabrics of cotton, certified as containing 100 percent pima cotton grown in the United States for making men's and boys' shirts, free of duty until 12/31/2005. The curr_chunk mentions the use of imported fabrics for making men's and boys' shirts under the Andean Trade Preference Act. The U.S. Notes to chapter 99 are amended to define "making" as cutting and sewing in the United States for subheadings 9902.52.08 and 9902.52.09. The quantity of cotton fabrics entered under subheading 9902.52.08 is limited to 85 percent of the total imported cotton woven fabric used for cutting and sewing men's and boys' shirts in the United States by each manufacturer. The Secretary of Commerce issues licenses to eligible manufacturers for importing cotton woven fabrics under subheading 9902.52.08 with annual quantity restrictions. Licensees can assign import authority to others. The Secretary of Commerce issues licenses to eligible manufacturers for importing cotton woven fabrics under specific restrictions. Manufacturers must provide a notarized affidavit stating the quantity of imported fabric purchased for use in the cutting and sewing of shirts in the United States. The date of purchase is determined based on whether the manufacturer is the importer of record. The Pima Cotton Trust Fund is established. The Pima Cotton Trust Fund is established within the Treasury of the United States, consisting of transferred amounts from the general fund starting October 1, 2005. The Pima Cotton Trust Fund, established on October 1, 2005, includes subheadings from the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. The Secretary is limited to transferring $16,000,000 annually to the Trust Fund, with no transfers allowed after October 1, 2007. The Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection will distribute 25 percent of the Trust Fund amounts annually starting in fiscal year 2005. The Pima Cotton Trust Fund, established in 2005, allocates 25 percent of its amounts annually to promote pima cotton grown in the US for textile and apparel goods. Another 25 percent is paid to yarn spinners of US-grown pima cotton based on their production of specific yarn types in 2002. The Trust Fund allocates 50 percent of its amounts annually to US manufacturers who cut and sew cotton shirts using imported cotton fabric from 1998 to 2003. The allocation is based on the dollar value of imported woven fabric. The Trust Fund allocates funds annually to US manufacturers who use imported woven cotton shirting fabric of 80s or higher count and 2-ply in warp for making men's and boys' cotton shirts. Manufacturers must provide a notarized affidavit to qualify for the allocation. Manufacturers must provide a notarized affidavit affirming the use of imported cotton fabric to cut and sew men's and boys' shirts in the US, along with details of the imported fabric purchased in 2002. The affidavit should also confirm the maintenance of invoices and supporting documentation showing the purchase details of the fabric. Manufacturers must provide a notarized affidavit affirming the use of imported cotton fabric to cut and sew men's and boys' shirts in the US. The affidavit should include details of the imported fabric purchased in 2002, such as the date of purchase, fabric specifications, and suitability for shirt manufacturing. Additionally, an affidavit from yarn spinners affirming the use of US-grown pima cotton to produce ring spun yarns is required. Manufacturers must provide documentation of the quantity and type of ring spun cotton yarns produced in 2002, measuring less than 83.33 decitex. Any payments made by the Commissioner of Customs and Border Protection are final and not subject to appeal. The decisions made by Customs and Border Protection under this section are final and cannot be appealed or protested.
